title: Amalgam
examples: a curious amalgam of the traditional and the modern.
an amalgam of strength, reputation, and commitment to ethical principles.
origin: late 15th century: from French amalgame or medieval Latin amalgama, from Greek malagma ‘an emollient’.

title: Galvanize
definition: shock or excite (someone) into taking action.

cases.text: shock or excite (someone) into taking action.
cases.use: the impassioned speach galvanized the onlookers

cases.text: coat (iron or steel) with a protective layer of zinc.
cases.use: it was a sample of galvanized steel

examples: the urgency of his voice galvanized them into action.
The country was galvanized in the weeks and months after 9/11.
origin: early 19th century (in the sense ‘stimulate by electricity’): from French galvaniser (see Galvani, Luigi).

title: Acrimony

cases.use: the acrimony in his words stung.

examples: the acrimony in his words stung.
Her acrimony for her neighbors manifests itself with shouting and stomping.
origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘bitter taste or smell’): from French acrimonie or Latin acrimonia, from acer, acri- ‘pungent, acrid’.

title: Arduous
definition: involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring
examples: the arduous work of preparing a Dictionary of the English Language.
origin: mid 16th century: from Latin arduus ‘steep, difficult’+ -ous.
